visuals.title: Unbiased BJT Common-Emitter Circuit
visuals.description: A sinusoidal source v_in connected through R_B to the base of an NPN transistor. No DC bias — the transistor relies entirely on the input signal.

visuals.title: Input vs Output: Signal Clipping Without Bias
visuals.description: The input sinusoid swings ±1 V. When v_in < 0.7 V the BJT cuts off → v_out = V_CC. Only peaks above 0.7 V produce output.

visuals.title: BJT Operating Regions — Where Should the Q-Point Be?
visuals.description: Three operating regions. Biasing places the Q-point in the ACTIVE region so the signal can swing without hitting cutoff or saturation.

visuals.title: The Solution: DC Bias + AC Signal → Full Amplification
visuals.description: Add a fixed DC voltage at the base so the transistor stays active. The signal rides on top of the DC bias.

visuals.title: With Proper Bias: Full Signal Amplified
visuals.description: DC bias keeps V_BE well above 0.7 V. The output is a clean, amplified, inverted sinusoid with no clipping.

visuals.title: Q-Point on the Output Characteristics
visuals.description: The Q-point sits in the middle of the active region on the I_C vs V_CE characteristics.

visuals.title: Signal Notation Convention
visuals.description: Four styles: Capital+Capital = DC, lower+lower = AC, lower+Capital = total, Capital+lower = phasor/RMS.

visuals.title: DC + AC = Total Signal at the Base
visuals.description: Total V_BE = DC bias (0.7 V) + small AC signal. The DC keeps the transistor on; the AC gets amplified.

visuals.title: Interactive: Explore Signal Clipping vs Bias Level
visuals.description: Adjust the waveform parameters to see how bias level affects signal clipping.

visuals.title: Coupling Capacitor: Blocking DC, Passing AC
visuals.description: C_in blocks DC (X_C = ∞ at ω = 0) and passes AC (X_C ≈ 0 at signal frequencies), protecting the DC bias.
